reviews.text: The generic dark fantasy storyline is pointless
the worst-in-class textures and character models suck any visual appeal out of what could have been an interesting painted-canvas art style
Combat and level design are both competent but plain in single-player or co-op, with just enough good ideas sprinkled in to keep things from immediately growing stale… though it inevitably does
Each level follows the same template: You load into a quest and run from point A to point B, navigating linear corridors as you race to your objective
A noticeable, persistent input lag, coupled with an unusually flat arc, makes gauging jumps more frustrating than it should be
The ability to level up a favorite piece of equipment is held until late in the campaign...forces you to jump around between different weapon combinations
the endgame...has its share of pitfalls that make the idea of sinking more time into Babylon’s Fall unappealing
Babylon’s Fall offers both free and premium versions of its battle pass...it’s always disappointing to see pay-to-win scenarios
joining up with a group of Sentinels has no strategic value beyond making missions pass more quickly
the painterly art direction had potential to be interesting, but it never gets the chance because Babylon’s Fall is one of the worst-looking games
Battling an undead dragon...is just another hit box to tune out to while you stare at a health bar, running the same sequence of attacks
Randomized enchantments add a much-needed element of unpredictability
There is a hub town shared by players with quest boards, item shops, and a blacksmith...but there is little incentive to try and create synergy between one loadout and another
Babylon’s Fall just isn’t good. It’s not terrible or broken, it just 'is'
Platinum Games’ answer to these prompts are Sentinel, Babylon, the Gallus, and Gideon Coffin, respectively – there’s nothing remotely memorable about any of those things except the last
The story is largely told in exposition-heavy still images, zooming from one fibrous picture frame to another
Lighting is almost non-existent, and NPCs all look like they were made by a random character generator from the mid 2000s
Knights with unsettling body proportions battle you in one area, while you face off against a giant spider/human hybrid with a skull for an abdomen in others
Transparent barriers occasionally form around you to create a sealed arena in which you’re barraged by waves of generic enemies until you slay an arbitrary number of foes
Environmental hazards like pits, spikes, and lava do just enough to keep at least some attention on the field of play, but it is easy to zone out
One has you ducking for cover at regular intervals as a dragon strafes the battlefield with fire, while another has you ascending a mountain by leaping from one floating platform to another
some – like the sphere that protects you from a hazardous atmosphere at the expense of disabling your best attacks – are genuinely annoying
against tougher enemies it does devolve into extended bouts of pure button-mashing while you watch health bars slowly decrease
There are limited archetypes in each category so you will see the exact same swords and hammers dozens of times
there are no character classes with defined roles like damage-dealing, tanking, or support
rewards tiers could potentially affect player performance, including crafting materials used to create weapons and armor, and Conches, the in-game currency that can be used to purchase XP boosts
Babylon’s Fall feels like the generic store brand of more famous games that came before
